TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit Information extends System.Object
.class public auto ansi sealed Information extends System.Object

Docs.summary: The module contains the procedures used to return, test for, or verify information.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This module supports the Visual Basic language keywords and run-time library members that provide error information, validate data, determine array bounds, and retrieve data type and color information.
## Examples The following example uses the `VbTypeName` function to return data type names for several variables.
```vb Dim sysDateName As String = "System.DateTime" Dim sysShortName As String = "Int16" Dim sysBadName As String = "Nonsense" Dim testVbName As String testVbName = VbTypeName(sysDateName) ' Returns "Date". testVbName = VbTypeName(sysShortName) ' Returns "Short". testVbName = VbTypeName(sysBadName) ' Returns Nothing. ```

Public Function Erl () As Integer
public: static int Erl();
static member Erl : unit -> int

Docs.summary: Returns an integer indicating the line number of the last executed statement. Read-only.
Docs.returns: Returns an integer indicating the line number of the last executed statement. Read-only.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If Visual Basic encounters no line numbers, it returns 0.
## Examples This example uses the `Erl` property to indicate the line number.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrErrorHandling#6](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrErrorHandling/VB/Class1.vb#6)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static Microsoft.VisualBasic.ErrObject Err ();
.method public static hidebysig class Microsoft.VisualBasic.ErrObject Err() cil managed
Public Function Err () As ErrObject
public: static Microsoft::VisualBasic::ErrObject ^ Err();
static member Err : unit -> Microsoft.VisualBasic.ErrObject
.method public static class Microsoft.VisualBasic.ErrObject Err() cil managed

remarks.format:
## Remarks The properties of the `Err` object are set by the generator of an error - Visual Basic, an object, or the programmer.
When a run-time error occurs, the properties of the `Err` object are filled with information that uniquely identifies the error and that you can use to handle the error. To generate a run-time error in your code, use the `Raise` method.
The `Err` object's properties are reset to zero or zero-length strings ("") after an `Exit Sub`, `Exit Function`, `Exit Property`, or `Resume Next` statement within an error-handling routine. Using any form of the `Resume` statement outside of an error-handling routine will not reset the `Err` object's properties. You can use the `Clear` method to explicitly reset `Err`.
Use the `Raise` method rather than the `Error` statement to generate run-time errors for system errors and class modules. Your decision about whether to use the `Raise` method in other code depends on the richness of the information you want to return.
The `Err` object is an intrinsic object with global scope. Therefore, you do not need to create an instance of it in your code.
## Examples This example uses the properties of the `Err` object in constructing an error-message dialog box. Notice that if you use the `Clear` method first, when you generate a Visual Basic error with the `Raise` method, Visual Basic's default values become the properties of the `Err` object.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrErrorHandling#3](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrErrorHandling/VB/Class1.vb#3)]

Docs.summary: Returns a value indicating whether a variable points to an array.
Docs.returns: Returns a value indicating whether a variable points to an array.

remarks.format:
## Remarks `IsArray` returns `True` if the variable points to an array; otherwise, it returns `False`. `IsArray` is especially useful with objects that might contain arrays.
## Examples This example uses the `IsArray` function to check if several variables refer to an array.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrFunctions#34](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrFunctions/VB/Class1.vb#34)]

Docs.summary: Returns a value indicating whether an expression represents a valid value.
Docs.returns: Returns a value indicating whether an expression represents a valid value.

remarks.format:
## Remarks `IsDate` returns `True` if `Expression` is of the <xref:System.DateTime> data type or can be converted to it; otherwise, it returns `False`.
The <xref:System.DateTime> data type holds both a date value and a time value. `IsDate` returns `True` if `Expression` represents a valid date, a valid time, or a valid date and time.
## Examples The following example uses the `IsDate` function to determine if several variables represent valid <xref:System.DateTime> values.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrFunctions#35](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrFunctions/VB/Class1.vb#35)]
In the preceding example, `IsDate` returns `True` for the first four calls and `False` for the last call.

MemberSignature.Value: public static bool IsDBNull (object Expression);

public: static bool IsDBNull(System::Object ^ Expression);

.method public static bool IsDBNull(object Expression) cil managed

Docs.summary: Returns a value indicating whether an expression evaluates to the class.
Docs.returns: Returns a value indicating whether an expression evaluates to the class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks `IsDBNull` returns `True` if the data type of `Expression` evaluates to the <xref:System.DBNull> type; otherwise, `IsDBNull` returns `False`.
The <xref:System.DBNull?displayProperty=nameWithType> value indicates that the `Object` represents missing or nonexistent data. `DBNull` is not the same as `Nothing`, which indicates that a variable has not yet been initialized. `DBNull` is also not the same as a zero-length string (`""`), which is sometimes referred to as a null string.
## Examples This example uses the `IsDBNull` function to determine if a variable evaluates to `DBNull`.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrFunctions#36](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrFunctions/VB/Class1.vb#36)]

Docs.summary: Returns a value indicating whether an expression is an exception type.
Docs.returns: Returns a value indicating whether an expression is an exception type.

remarks.format:
## Remarks `IsError` returns `True` if the expression represents an `Object` variable that derives from the <xref:System.Exception> class in the <xref:System> namespace.
An exception that derives from <xref:System.Exception?displayProperty=nameWithType> can be caught with the `Try...Catch...Finally` statements.
## Examples The following example uses the `IsError` function to check if an expression represents a system exception.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrFunctions#37](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrFunctions/VB/Class1.vb#37)]

Docs.summary: Returns a value indicating whether an expression has no object assigned to it.
Docs.returns: Returns a value indicating whether an expression has no object assigned to it.

remarks.format:
## Remarks `IsNothing` returns `True` if the expression represents an object variable that currently has no object assigned to it; otherwise, it returns `False`.
`IsNothing` is intended to work on reference types. A value type cannot hold a value of [Nothing](~/docs/visual-basic/language-reference/nothing.md) and reverts to its default value if you assign `Nothing` to it. If you supply a value type in `Expression`, `IsNothing` always returns `False`.
## Examples The following example uses the `IsNothing` function to determine if an object variable is associated with any object instance.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrFunctions#38](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrFunctions/VB/Class1.vb#38)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static bool IsNumeric (object Expression);
.method public static hidebysig bool IsNumeric(object Expression) cil managed
Public Function IsNumeric (Expression As Object) As Boolean
public: static bool IsNumeric(System::Object ^ Expression);
static member IsNumeric : obj -> bool
.method public static bool IsNumeric(object Expression) cil managed

Docs.summary: Returns a value indicating whether an expression can be evaluated as a number.
Docs.returns: Returns a value indicating whether an expression can be evaluated as a number.

remarks.format:
## Remarks `IsNumeric` returns `True` if the data type of `Expression` is `Boolean`, `Byte`, `Decimal`, `Double`, `Integer`, `Long`, `SByte`, `Short`, `Single`, `UInteger`, `ULong`, or `UShort`. It also returns `True` if `Expression` is a `Char`, `String`, or `Object` that can be successfully converted to a number. `Expression` can contain non-numeric characters. `IsNumeric` returns `True` if `Expression` is a string that contains a valid hexadecimal or octal number. `IsNumeric` also returns `True` if `Expression` contains a valid numeric expression that begins with a + or - character or contains commas.
`IsNumeric` returns `False` if `Expression` is of data type `Date`. It returns `False` if `Expression` is a `Char`, `String`, or `Object` that cannot be successfully converted to a number.
## Examples The following example uses the `IsNumeric` function to determine if the contents of a variable can be evaluated as a number.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrFunctions#39](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrFunctions/VB/Class1.vb#39)]

public: static bool IsReference(System::Object ^ Expression);

.method public static bool IsReference(object Expression) cil managed

Docs.summary: Returns a value indicating whether an expression evaluates to a reference type.
Docs.returns: Returns a value indicating whether an expression evaluates to a reference type.

remarks.format:
## Remarks `IsReference` returns `True` if `Expression` represents a reference type, such as a class instance, a `String` type, or an array of any type; otherwise, it returns `False`.
A reference type contains a pointer to data stored elsewhere in memory. A value type contains its own data.
## Examples This example uses the `IsReference` function to check if several variables refer to reference types.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrFunctions#40](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrFunctions/VB/Class1.vb#40)]
In the preceding example, the first three calls to `IsReference` return `True`. The last call returns `False`, because `Integer` is a value type, not a reference type.

MemberSignature.Value: public static int LBound (Array Array, int Rank = 1);
.method public static hidebysig int32 LBound(class System.Array Array, int32 Rank) cil managed
Public Function LBound (Array As Array, Optional Rank As Integer = 1) As Integer
static member LBound : Array * int -> int
.method public static int32 LBound(class System.Array Array, int32 Rank) cil managed

Docs.param: Required. Array of any data type. The array in which you want to find the lowest possible subscript of a dimension.
Optional. . The dimension for which the lowest possible subscript is to be returned. Use 1 for the first dimension, 2 for the second, and so on. If is omitted, 1 is assumed.
Docs.summary: Returns the lowest available subscript for the indicated dimension of an array.
Docs.returns: . The lowest value the subscript for the specified dimension can contain. always returns 0 as long as has been initialized, even if it has no elements, for example if it is a zero-length string. If is , throws an .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Since array subscripts start at 0, the lowest available subscript for every dimension is always 0.
For an array with the following dimensions, `LBound` returns the values in the following table:
```vb Dim a(100, 5, 4) As Byte ```
|Call to LBound|Return value| |--------------------|------------------| |`LBound(a, 1)`|0| |`LBound(a, 2)`|0| |`LBound(a, 3)`|0|
## Examples The following example uses the `LBound` function to determine the lowest available subscript for the indicated dimension of an array.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrFunctions#41](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrFunctions/VB/Class1.vb#41)]

Docs.exception: less than 1, or is greater than the rank of .

MemberSignature.Value: public static int QBColor (int Color);
.method public static hidebysig int32 QBColor(int32 Color) cil managed
Public Function QBColor (Color As Integer) As Integer
public: static int QBColor(int Color);
static member QBColor : int -> int
.method public static int32 QBColor(int32 Color) cil managed

Docs.param: Required. A whole number in the range 0-15.
Docs.summary: Returns an value representing the RGB color code corresponding to the specified color number.
Docs.returns: Returns an value representing the RGB color code corresponding to the specified color number.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Starting with the least-significant byte, the returned value specifies the red, green, and blue values used to set the appropriate color in the RGB system used by the Visual Basic language.
The `Color` argument has these settings.
|Number|Color|Number|Color| |------------|-----------|------------|-----------| |0|Black|8|Gray| |1|Blue|9|Light blue| |2|Green|10|Light green| |3|Cyan|11|Light cyan| |4|Red|12|Light red| |5|Magenta|13|Light magenta| |6|Yellow|14|Light yellow| |7|White|15|Bright white|
## Examples This example uses the `QBColor` function to change to the color indicated by `colorInteger`. `QBColor` accepts integer values between 0 and 15.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrCatRef#29](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrCatRef/VB/Class1.vb#29)]

Docs.exception: is outside of range 0 to 15, inclusive.

MemberSignature.Value: public static int RGB (int Red, int Green, int Blue);
.method public static hidebysig int32 RGB(int32 Red, int32 Green, int32 Blue) cil managed
Public Function RGB (Red As Integer, Green As Integer, Blue As Integer) As Integer
public: static int RGB(int Red, int Green, int Blue);
static member RGB : int * int * int -> int
.method public static int32 RGB(int32 Red, int32 Green, int32 Blue) cil managed

Docs.param: Required. in the range 0-255, inclusive, that represents the intensity of the red component of the color.
Required. in the range 0-255, inclusive, that represents the intensity of the green component of the color.
Required. in the range 0-255, inclusive, that represents the intensity of the blue component of the color.
Docs.summary: Returns an value representing an RGB color value from a set of red, green and blue color components.
Docs.returns: Returns an value representing an RGB color value from a set of red, green and blue color components.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Application methods and properties that accept a color specification expect that specification to be a number representing an RGB color value. An RGB color value specifies the relative intensity of red, green, and blue to cause a specific color to be displayed.
If the value for any argument to `RGB` is greater than 255, 255 is used.
The following table lists some standard colors and the red, green, and blue values they include.
|Color|Red value|Green value|Blue value| |-----------|---------------|-----------------|----------------| |Black|0|0|0| |Blue|0|0|255| |Green|0|255|0| |Cyan|0|255|255| |Red|255|0|0| |Magenta|255|0|255| |Yellow|255|255|0| |White|255|255|255|
## Examples This example shows how the `RGB` function is used to return a whole number representing an `RGB` color value.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrCatRef#18](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrCatRef/VB/Class1.vb#18)]

Docs.exception: , , or is outside of range 0 to 255, inclusive.

MemberSignature.Value: public static string SystemTypeName (string VbName);
.method public static hidebysig string SystemTypeName(string VbName) cil managed
Public Function SystemTypeName (VbName As String) As String
public: static System::String ^ SystemTypeName(System::String ^ VbName);
static member SystemTypeName : string -> string
.method public static string SystemTypeName(string VbName) cil managed

Docs.param: Required. A variable containing a Visual Basic type name.
Docs.summary: Returns a value containing the system data type name of a variable.
Docs.returns: Returns a value containing the system data type name of a variable.

remarks.format:
## Remarks `SystemTypeName` returns the fully qualified common language runtime (CLR) type name corresponding to the Visual Basic type name. For example, if `VbName` contains "Date", `SystemTypeName` returns "System.DateTime". If `SystemTypeName` does not recognize the value of `VbName`, it returns `Nothing` (not the string "Nothing").
## Examples The following example uses the `SystemTypeName` function to return data type names for several variables.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrFunctions#49](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrFunctions/VB/Class1.vb#49)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static string TypeName (object VarName);
.method public static hidebysig string TypeName(object VarName) cil managed
Public Function TypeName (VarName As Object) As String
public: static System::String ^ TypeName(System::Object ^ VarName);
static member TypeName : obj -> string
.method public static string TypeName(object VarName) cil managed

Docs.param: Required. variable. If is , you can pass a variable of any data type except a structure.
Docs.summary: Returns a value containing data-type information about a variable.
Docs.returns: Returns a value containing data-type information about a variable.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The following table shows the `String` values returned by `TypeName` for different contents of `VarName`.
|`VarName` contents|String returned| |------------------------|---------------------| |16-bit `True` or `False` value type|"Boolean"| |8-bit binary value type|"Byte"| |16-bit character value type|"Char"| |64-bit date and time value type|"Date"| |Reference type indicating missing or nonexistent data|"DBNull"| |128-bit fixed-point numeric value type|"Decimal"| |64-bit floating-point numeric value type|"Double"| |32-bit integer value type|"Integer"| |Reference type pointing to an unspecialized object|"Object"| |Reference type pointing to a specialized object created from class *objectclass*|"*objectclass*"| |64-bit integer value type|"Long"| |Reference type with no object currently assigned to it|"Nothing"| |8-bit signed integer value type|"SByte"| |16-bit integer value type|"Short"| |32-bit floating-point numeric value type|"Single"| |Reference type pointing to a string of 16-bit characters|"String"| |32-bit unsigned integer value type|"UInteger"| |64-bit unsigned integer value type|"ULong"| |16-bit unsigned integer value type|"UShort"|
If `VarName` is an array, the returned string can be any one of the strings in the preceding table with empty parentheses appended. For example, if `VarName` points to an array of integers, `TypeName` returns "Integer()".
When `TypeName` returns the name of a reference type such as a class, it returns only the name itself, not the qualified name. For example, if `VarName` points to an object of class <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PaperSource?displayProperty=nameWithType>, `TypeName` returns "PaperSource". Note that if the variable is declared to be of a certain class type but does not have an object assigned to it, `TypeName` returns "Nothing".
## Examples The following example uses the `TypeName` function to return data type information about several variables.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrFunctions#52](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrFunctions/VB/Class1.vb#52)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static int UBound (Array Array, int Rank = 1);
.method public static hidebysig int32 UBound(class System.Array Array, int32 Rank) cil managed
Public Function UBound (Array As Array, Optional Rank As Integer = 1) As Integer
static member UBound : Array * int -> int
.method public static int32 UBound(class System.Array Array, int32 Rank) cil managed

Docs.param: Required. Array of any data type. The array in which you want to find the highest possible subscript of a dimension.
Optional. . The dimension for which the highest possible subscript is to be returned. Use 1 for the first dimension, 2 for the second, and so on. If is omitted, 1 is assumed.
Docs.summary: Returns the highest available subscript for the indicated dimension of an array.
Docs.returns: . The highest value the subscript for the specified dimension can contain. If has only one element, returns 0. If has no elements, for example if it is a zero-length string, returns -1.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Since array subscripts start at 0, the length of a dimension is greater by one than the highest available subscript for that dimension.
For an array with the following dimensions, `UBound` returns the values in the following table:
```vb Dim a(100, 5, 4) As Byte ```
|Call to UBound|Return value| |--------------------|------------------| |`UBound(a, 1)`|100| |`UBound(a, 2)`|5| |`UBound(a, 3)`|4|
You can use `UBound` to determine the total number of elements in an array, but you must adjust the value it returns to account for the fact that the subscripts start at 0. The following example calculates the total size of the array `a` in the preceding example:
```vb Dim total As Integer total = (UBound(A, 1) + 1) * (UBound(A, 2) + 1) * (UBound(A, 3) + 1) ```
The value calculated for `total` is 3030, which is 101 * 6 * 5.
## Examples The following example uses the `UBound` function to determine the highest available subscript for the indicated dimension of an array.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrFunctions#53](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrFunctions/VB/Class1.vb#53)]

Docs.exception: is less than 1, or is greater than the rank of .

static member VarType : obj -> Microsoft.VisualBasic.VariantType
.method public static valuetype Microsoft.VisualBasic.VariantType VarType(object VarName) cil managed

Docs.param: Required. variable. If is , you can pass a variable of any data type except a structure.
Docs.summary: Returns an value containing the data type classification of a variable.
Docs.returns: Returns an value containing the data type classification of a variable.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The integer value returned by `VarType` is a member of the <xref:Microsoft.VisualBasic.VariantType>.
The following table shows the values returned by `VarType` for special cases of `VarName`.
|Data type represented by `VarName`|Value returned by `VarType`| |----------------------------------------|---------------------------------| |[Nothing](~/docs/visual-basic/language-reference/nothing.md)|`VariantType.Object`| |<xref:System.DBNull>|`VariantType.Null`| |Enumeration|Underlying data type (`SByte`, `Byte`, `Short`, `UShort`, `Integer`, `UInteger`, `Long`, or `ULong`)| |Array|Bitwise OR of array element type and `VariantType.Array`| |Array of arrays|Bitwise OR of `VariantType.Object` and `VariantType.Array`| |Structure (<xref:System.ValueType?displayProperty=nameWithType>)|`VariantType.UserDefinedType`| |<xref:System.Exception>|`VariantType.Error`| |Unknown|`VariantType.Object`|
## Examples The following example uses the `VarType` function to return data type classification information about several variables.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrFunctions#55](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrFunctions/VB/Class1.vb#55)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static string VbTypeName (string UrtName);
.method public static hidebysig string VbTypeName(string UrtName) cil managed
Public Function VbTypeName (UrtName As String) As String
public: static System::String ^ VbTypeName(System::String ^ UrtName);
static member VbTypeName : string -> string
.method public static string VbTypeName(string UrtName) cil managed

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.param: Required. variable containing a type name used by the common language runtime.
Docs.summary: Returns a value containing the Visual Basic data type name of a variable.
Docs.returns: Returns a value containing the Visual Basic data type name of a variable.

remarks.format:
## Remarks `VbTypeName` returns the Visual Basic type name corresponding to the common language runtime type name. For example, if `UrtName` contains "Int32" or "System.Int32", `VbTypeName` returns "Integer". If `VbTypeName` does not recognize the value of `UrtName`, it returns `Nothing` (not the string "Nothing").
The type name in `UrtName` can be obtained from various sources, for example from the <xref:System.Reflection.MemberInfo.Name%2A> property in the <xref:System.Reflection.MemberInfo> array of the <xref:System.Type> class.
## Examples The following example uses the `VbTypeName` function to return data type names for several variables.
[!code-vb[VbVbalrFunctions#56](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_VBCSharp/VbVbalrFunctions/VB/Class1.vb#56)]
